repnme.cdata!: Chad - Agricultural and Livestock Services Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings assess project outcomes as
            satisfactory, despite an unlikely sustainability, and modest
            institutional development impacts. Lessons show that
            adapting an effective, agricultural extension management
            system to the conditions of the country, substantially
            exceed the high costs involved in establishing and modifying
            extension management, as based on the increased
            productivity. Whereas support by adaptive and participative
            agricultural research is necessary, initially though, the
            best practices of existing traditional known technology, may
            well provide the adequate training material, tested on
            farmers' fields, further allowing substantial
            productivity, and income improvements. Although the cotton
            sector was not specifically included in the project, an
            important lesson drawn from the project suggests that
            specific measures could have been taken to support a sector
            as critical as cotton is in Chad, following the decline of
            cotton prices. Nongovernmental organizations (NGOs), and
            bilateral agencies can be effective implementation agencies
            for special types of components, though not necessarily less
            expensive than Government agencies. To this end, the high
            administrative, and operational costs absorbed by NGOs,
            require that measures be developed to reduce costs. The use
            of producer organizations as a basis for village
            investments, provide benefits beyond those strictly
            economic: provides a forum to fight HIV/AIDS; promotes the
            position of women; and, improves communal, environmental understanding.

18155525.projn:
TD-Agricultural And Livestock Services
            Project -- P000501
18155525.theme: Other rural development,Rural policies and institutions,Participation and civic engagement,Technology diffusion

repnme.cdata!:
Chad - Agricultural and Livestock Services
            Program Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Agricultural and Livestock Services
            Project is the first phase in a six-year plan, which aims to
            increase agricultural productivity in an environmentally
            sustainable manner, to improve producers' incomes, and
            to rationalize the use of public resources in support of
            rural services. The specific objectives of the project are
            to: 1) reshape extension into an effective service
            addressing farmer's needs for improved crop and
            livestock production as well as for natural resources
            management; 2) strengthen linkages between extension and
            research focusing on participatory and adaptive research;
            and 3) strengthen and build up producer's
            organizations. The components of the project are as follows:
            1) extension service activities which will progressively
            cover the country's fourteen "prefectures",
            for crop and livestock production, and natural resource
            management; 2) the establishment of a minimum research
            capacity, through collaboration among researchers, producers
            and extension agents, to develop, test and promote improved
            production practices and technologies; and 3) the
            enhancement of the capacity of producers'
            organizations, through training and technical assistance, to
            carry out group activities such as crop and produce
            marketing, management and distribution of farm inputs,
            maintenance of agricultural equipment and basic animal
            health care.
